You always have the option to delete your Tweet location history. Learn more
summary: A man suspected of killing a Texas state trooper during a traffic stop was taken into custody more than 100 miles away, authorities said Thursday night. The Harris County Sheriff's Office announced on Twitter that the suspect was apprehended in neighboring Waller County. The Texas Department of Public Safety and other law enforcement agencies identified the suspect as Dabrett Black, 32, of Lindale, Texas, the AP reports. DPS said the trooper was shot and killed before 4pm Thursday during a traffic stop on Interstate 45 near Fairfield, about 90 miles south of Dallas. The trooper, who has not been publicly identified, was shot with a rifle and died at the scene, the agency said. The suspect then fled. Hours after the shooting, the Waller County Sheriff's Office said the suspect's vehicle was spotted in Hempstead. The sheriff's office said shots were fired but didn't indicate who opened fire. The suspect was apprehended a short time later. Several Texas officials reacted to the trooper's death. In a tweet, Sen. Ted Cruz offered "prayers for the family and loved ones" of the trooper. Gov. Greg Abbott called the trooper's killing a "heinous crime." "Sad on Thanksgiving to lose one of our state troopers in the line of duty," he tweeted. "Prayers for his family. Swift justice for his killer."

text: NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Officials said the "person of interest" detained early Monday in connection with a string of more than 50 deliberately set fires has been arrested and is expected to be booked on arson charges later in the afternoon. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR N o new arsons have been reported since the suspect was taken into custody, but police stressed that the investigation is ongoing. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The fires have caused $2 million in damage, authorities said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR MAP: Arson fires NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR At a news conference Monday, officials said the arson task force is sifting through about 100 clues in the case. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Los Angeles Police Chief Charlie Beck, interviewed at the Rose Parade by City News Service, said: "I feel very good that we've got the right guy. [The suspect] had the right stuff in his van, and we are very confident we found our man.'' NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The suspect is a native of Germany who may have been in dispute with federal immigration officials, sources said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR PHOTOS: Arson fires NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The man appears to have been battling the U.S. government over the immigration status of a relative, but the officials said they don't know if this played any role in the arson case. The Los Angeles Police Department is in communication with federal immigration officials concerning the dispute, the law enforcement sources said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR LAPD detectives found materials inside the man's minivan that could have been used to set fires, the sources said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR All the sources spoke on the condition of anonymity because the case is ongoing. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR FULL COVERAGE: Arson fires NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Little is known about the suspect. Sources said the minivan had Canadian license plates but that detectives say the man is from Germany. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The man was detained near a drugstore at the corner of Fairfax Avenue and Sunset Boulevard early Monday morning, according to a witness to the incident. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Several sources said the man is believed to be the same person seen in a surveillance video released by police Sunday, when authorities pointed to the individual as a "person of interest" in the case.  When the man police have identified as a "person of interest" in Los Angeles' spate of recent arson attacks was sitting in the back of a squad car early Monday morning, a small group of witnesses gave him "the finger"-- and he returned the gesture with a smile, one witness said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "It was creepy," said Rick Savage, a music producer who saw the incident at the intersection of Sunset Boulevard and Fairfax Avenue. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Savage said he was awake because he has been nervous about the string of arsons in recent days in his and other nearby neighborhoods. He said he had downloaded a police scanner application onto his iPad and went to the area at about 3:15 a.m. after hearing reports that authorities had tracked a person of interest in the case. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR MAP: Arson fires NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "For the past three nights, it's been freaking me out," Savage said of the fires. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Aaron Arellano, who works the graveyard shift at a gas station across from where authorities stopped a blue minivan with the man inside, said that at first there were only three squad cars near the minivan. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Then "little by little" more police and fire vehicles arrived until there was a mass of about two dozen on Sunset Boulevard, said the 28-year-old Arrelano. He said police officers -- some of whom came into the gas station for coffee -- told him they had caught "one of the arsonists." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR PHOTOS: Arson fires NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Earlier Monday morning, police had stationed patrol cars throughout the affected areas and for a while set up checkpoints at some intersections. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR There were so many patrol cars and officers involved in the hunt that at one point Monday morning there were more than a dozen squad cars from the LAPD's Central Division on Ventura Boulevard, called in for additional help. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The cars were stopped near one of the recent fires that had destroyed a car parked outside a single-family home on Sunnyslope Avenue in Sherman Oaks. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR RELATED: NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR FULL COVERAGE: Arson fires NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Suspect arrested in string of fires NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Police examine immigration link to case NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR -- Ari Bloomekatz in Hollywood NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Photo: Police investigate a minivan officials say may be linked to a series of arson fires. Credit: Rick Loomis / Los Angeles Times NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Map: Shows locations of fires possibly linked to recent arson spree. Credit: Los Angeles Times
summary: The "person of interest" detained earlier today in Los Angeles' string of arsons has been arrested, reports the Los Angeles Times. "I feel very good that we've got the right guy," says LA Police Chief Charlie Beck. He "had the right stuff in his van, and we are very confident we found our man.'' Indeed, there have been no new fires since the suspect was detained. Police say that the suspect is a German who was embroiled in a fight with federal immigration authorities. Meanwhile, sources tell the Times that they spotted the suspect in the back of a police cruiser, and a number of them flipped him the bird—a gesture he returned with an eerie smile. "It was creepy," says a music producer who witnessed the exchange. Click for more on the case.

text: General Mills NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Although we have nothing against Lucky Charms cereal as a whole, we’ve got to admit: The marshmallow charms are and always will be the best part. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR And it looks like the good people over at General Mills (the HQ for all things Lucky Charms) are finally listening up. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR According to the General Mills blog, the company is releasing limited-edition marshmallow-only boxes after receiving “countless calls, emails, tweets, and Facebook posts” from fans begging for the cereal-free cereal. That’s right: A whole box filled with nothing but the classic, sugar-y marshmallow shapes. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR RELATED: Kylie Jenner Requests Lucky Charms Marshmallows Only — and Receives a One-of-a-Kind Box NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Of course, there’s a catch. Only 10 boxes of Marshmallow Only Lucky Charms will be available to the public. So, how do you get your hands on a “unicorn of the cereal world?” They can only be won via social media: The cereal manufacturer is asking fans to post a selfie of themselves holding an imaginary box of Lucky Charms (with the hashtag #Lucky10Sweepstakes) on Twitter or Instagram. Then, from the entries, 10 winners will be chosen. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR For the full rules, you’ll have to watch a video of Biz Markie rapping the fine print to the tune of his song “Just a Friend.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR RELATED: John Mayer Tweets Cookie Dough Almond Butter Into Existence NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The brand previously gifted Kylie Jenner, Blake Shelton and Jessie Pitts custom boxes, while Khloé Kardashian revealed that she keeps a stash of them in her super-organized pantry. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR —Grace Gavilanes  news NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Oct 14, 2015 • By Ashley Halladay NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Win a box of Marshmallow Only Lucky Charms NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A box of Marshmallow Only Lucky Charms has always been the unicorn of the cereal world – fantasized about, but never seen. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Lucky Charms team receives countless calls, emails, tweets and Facebook posts from marshmallow-obsessed fans longing for a box filled with only the magically-delicious marshmallows. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Well marshmallow maniacs, Marshmallow Only Lucky Charms are here! NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Yes, you read that correctly. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR But there is a catch. There are only 10 boxes available. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR So, how can you become one of the Lucky 10? NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR It’s simple! Just share a photo of yourself holding an imaginary box of Lucky Charms on Facebook, Twitter or Instagram between October 14 and 18 using #Lucky10Sweepstakes. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Watch the #Lucky10Sweepstakes video, here. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR And yes, that’s Biz Markie! Why Biz? Well, the brand team says “he’s just a friend” with a great remix to sing about the Lucky 10. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Watch another #Lucky10Sweepstakes video, here. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The sweepstakes will live exclusively in social media because that’s where Lucky Charms fans continuously express their love for the brand, especially the marshmallows. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “We wanted to tap into where that love is and it’s across Facebook, Twitter and Instagram. Lucky Charms is one of the most Instagrammed cereals and these platforms are the right place to ignite and connect to the passion we hear about,” says Amanda Hill, associate marketing manager, Lucky Charms. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Marshmallow Only sweepstakes is a way for the brand to show fans some love in return. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “We wanted to have a little fun and connect with our fans. It needed to be easy and accessible for everyone to have a chance to win and celebrate what makes us, us – the marshmallows,” Amanda says. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Let the marshmallow mania commence! NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR *The sweepstakes ends October 18. You must be 18 to enter and a legal resident of the United States or District of Columbia. There are three ways to enter- via Facebook, Twitter or Instagram. Limit of three entries per person, one per entry method. Potential winners will be notified on or around Oct. 20, 2015. For full rules and regulations, visit the Lucky Charms Facebook page. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Subscribe to “A Taste of General Mills” by email – here – and we’ll notify you about our latest posts.
summary: Big news for fans of sugary breakfast cereals and social-media-driven brand promotions: Lucky Charms is giving people the chance to win "the unicorn of the cereal world," a box of Marshmallow Only Lucky Charms, People reports. According to General Mills, the contest is in response to the constant requests the company gets for an all-marshmallow box of the cereal. Also, Biz Markie is involved for some reason. To win one of only 10 boxes being made available, post a selfie of yourself holding an imaginary box of Lucky Charms to Facebook, Twitter, or Instagram and tag it #Lucky10Sweepstakes by Sunday. Or, you know, just buy one of these.

text: Notice NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR You must log in to continue.  Every year, Ben Kinsey waves an American flag on a South Carolina bridge for 11 hours to honor victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR On Thursday, the veteran was seen standing alone on the bridge once again, but he was two months early. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR This time he was honoring the four U.S. Marines killed by a gunman who attacked two military facilities in Chattanooga, Tenn. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR South Carolina resident Noah Smith was driving home from work when he spotted Kinsey on the I-20 overpass and snapped a photo. Afterward, he shared the man's story on Facebook, and it quickly went viral. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I wonder what he was doing turned around, parked my car got out and walked up to him and said, 'Sir this is really awesome of you but why are you doing this?'" the North August resident shared in the Facebook post. "He replies with 'I'm standing out here for the four Marines killed today in TN. You know they can survive combat and come home during a peaceful time and get killed.'" NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The man told Smith he planned on staying on the bridge for four hours -- one for each Marine killed in the shootings. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "For the past three years, on 9/11, I've been standing on the bridge," Kinsey told CBS affiliate WRDW on Friday. "I try to do 11 hours to remember the folks who died on 9/11." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Dozens of Facebook users, including Whitney Degnan, say this isn't the first time they've seen Kinsey on the bridge. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Last year, Degnan was driving under the bridge on Sept. 11 when she saw him with a flag and pulled over to see if he was alright. He explained that he had spent time in the U.S. Marine Corp. and he would spend time on the bridge in remembrance of 9/11 "every year until he was dead." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR That's why Degnan wasn't surprised to see Kinsey on the bridge again. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I was surprised, but the same time I wasn't," Degnan told CBS News. "I saw the picture and automatically knew it was the same man. I was in awe because he is well over the age to be standing on a bridge in 100-degree weather, but he did and all for four people and the other thousands that he doesn't even know." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Hundreds of people on Facebook said they would like to stand with him next year. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I will stand with him, any one else?" one user commented. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Think everyone that agrees with and supports this man should go stand in that bridge? I'm down," another said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Degnan said she plans on visiting him again this year. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "[With] all these horrible things are happening around us, he will be the reminder that our country will forever stand tall," she said.
summary: Plenty of words of praise have been offered for the four Marines shot to death in Chattanooga yesterday, but it's a veteran's silent tribute that is resonating online. Ben Kinsey stood on a South Carolina bridge for four hours yesterday with an American flag, an hour for each victim, reports CBS News. He wasn't looking to call attention to the salute: It just so happened that Noah Smith saw Kinsey on the I-20 overpass and stopped to ask what was going on. His subsequent Facebook post has been shared more than 40,000 times. Smith writes that he parked his car and walked to Kinsey, saying, "'Sir this is really awesome of you but why are you doing this? He replies with 'I'm standing out here for the four Marines killed today in TN. You know they can survive combat and come home during a peaceful time and get killed.'" Kinsey tells CBS that he shows up on the bridge every Sept. 11 for an 11-hour tribute.

text: (CNN) Idaho State University has been fined after it lost track of a small amount of plutonium 239, a substance used to make nuclear weapons. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR University Officials say the sample, missing since 2003, does not pose a direct health issue or risk to public safety. The substance had been used by the school to conduct several research experiments. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The school realized it had lost track of the plutonium earlier this year and immediately notified the US Nuclear Regulatory Commission. ISU officials said the sample, weighing a gram, was lost as it was being taken out of service after employees only partially filled out the necessary paperwork. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Although the ISU believes the tiny speck of plutonium was transferred to a licensed disposal facility, there are no records to prove that it was. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The commission fined the university $8,500 for the lost plutonium. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Read More  FILE - In this May 11, 2015, file photo, nuclear waste is stored in underground containers at the Idaho Nation. A small amount of radioactive, weapons-grade plutonium about the size of a U.S. quarter... (Associated Press) NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR FILE - In this May 11, 2015, file photo, nuclear waste is stored in underground containers at the Idaho Nation. A small amount of radioactive, weapons-grade plutonium about the size of a U.S. quarter... (Associated Press) NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR BOISE, Idaho (AP) — A small amount of radioactive, weapons-grade plutonium about the size of a U.S. quarter is missing from an Idaho university that was using it for research, leading federal officials on Friday to propose an $8,500 fine. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Idaho State University can't account for about a 30th of an ounce (1 gram) of the material that's used in nuclear reactors and to make nuclear bombs. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The amount is too small to make a nuclear bomb, agency spokesman Victor Dricks said, but could be used to make a dirty bomb to spread radioactive contamination. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "The NRC has very rigorous controls for the use and storage of radioactive materials as evidenced by this enforcement action," he said of the proposed fine for failing to keep track of the material. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Dr. Cornelis Van der Schyf, vice president for research at the university, blamed partially completed paperwork from 15 years ago as the school tried to dispose of the plutonium. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Unfortunately, because there was a lack of sufficient historical records to demonstrate the disposal pathway employed in 2003, the source in question had to be listed as missing," he said in a statement to The Associated Press. "The radioactive source in question poses no direct health issue or risk to public safety." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Idaho State University has a nuclear engineering program and works with the U.S. Department of Energy's Idaho National Laboratory, considered the nation's primary nuclear research lab and located about 65 miles (105 kilometers) northwest of the school. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The plutonium was being used to develop ways to ensure nuclear waste containers weren't leaking and to find ways to detect radioactive material being illegally brought into the U.S. following the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, the school said in an email to the AP. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The university, which has 30 days to dispute the proposed fine, reported the plutonium missing on Oct. 13, according to documents released by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. The agency said a school employee doing a routine inventory discovered the university could only account for 13 of its 14 plutonium sources, each weighing about the same small amount. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The school searched documents and found records from 2003 and 2004 saying the material was on campus and awaiting disposal. However, there were no documents saying the plutonium had been properly disposed. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The last document mentioning the plutonium is dated Nov. 23, 2003. It said the Idaho National Laboratory didn't want the plutonium and the school's technical safety office had it "pending disposal of the next waste shipment." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The school also reviewed documents on waste barrels there and others transferred off campus since 2003, and opened and examined some of them. Finally, officials searched the campus but didn't find the plutonium. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The nuclear commission said senior university officials planned to return the school's remaining plutonium to the Energy Department. It's not clear if that has happened. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Energy Department officials didn't return calls seeking comment Friday. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Dricks, the commission spokesman, said returning the plutonium was part of the school's plan to reduce its inventory of radioactive material. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He said overall it has "a good record with the NRC." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR ___ NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR This story has been corrected to show that the missing plutonium is about a 30th of an ounce, not a third of an ounce.
summary: A university has admitted to misplacing a gram of weapons-grade plutonium, and federal authorities want to fine them $8,500. Per CNN, Idaho State University has not been able to account for the bit of radioactive material since 2003 but, nonetheless, believes it was properly stored at a licensed disposal facility. However, with no documented proof, the US Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Friday it must propose the fine. Dr. Cornelis Van der Schyf, vice president for research at the university, blamed partially completed paperwork from 15 years ago as the school tried to dispose of the plutonium. "Unfortunately, because there was a lack of sufficient historical records to demonstrate the disposal pathway employed in 2003, the source in question had to be listed as missing," he said in a statement to the AP. The statement said the plutonium "poses no direct health issue or risk to public safety." The plutonium was being used to develop ways to ensure nuclear waste containers weren't leaking and to find ways to detect radioactive material being illegally brought into the US following the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks. While the missing amount could not be used to make a nuclear bomb, it could be used to create a so-called dirty bomb to spread nuclear contamination. The university, which has 30 days to dispute the proposed fine, reported the plutonium missing on Oct. 13, according to documents released by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. The agency said a school employee doing a routine inventory discovered the university could only account for 13 of its 14 plutonium sources, each weighing about the same small amount.

text: Another day, another charitable donation by Taylor Swift. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The country music pop princess has vowed to help the victims of the devastating Louisiana floods by donating $1 million to the state’s disaster relief fund. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Big-hearted Swift, 26, released a statement to the Associated Press on Tuesday, August 16, revealing how warmly she was greeted by Louisiana residents when she performed there last year. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “We began the 1989 world tour in Louisiana, and the wonderful fans there made us feel completely at home," she said. "The fact that so many people in Louisiana have been forced out of their own homes this week is heartbreaking.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR So far 11 people have been killed by the historic flooding, which has damaged at least 40,000 homes. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “I encourage those who can to help out and send your love and prayers their way during this devastating time,” Swift added. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR This is far from the first time the singer — who has an estimated worth of $250 million — has dug deep for a good cause. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Last year she donated $50,000 to a young fan battling cancer, as well as giving the same amount to the nephew of her backup dancer, who was also suffering from the disease. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR In 2014 she donated $50,000 to the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia, and back in 2008 she gave $100,000 to the Red Cross in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, to help the victims of that flood too. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Sign up now for the Us Weekly newsletter to get breaking celebrity news, hot pics and more delivered straight to your inbox! NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR  FILE - In this April 3, 2016 file photo, Taylor Swift arrives at the iHeartRadio Music Awards at The Forum in Inglewood, Calif. Swift is donating $1 million to Louisiana after torrential rains caused... (Associated Press) NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR FILE - In this April 3, 2016 file photo, Taylor Swift arrives at the iHeartRadio Music Awards at The Forum in Inglewood, Calif. Swift is donating $1 million to Louisiana after torrential rains caused... (Associated Press) NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEW YORK (AP) — Taylor Swift is donating $1 million to Louisiana flood relief after torrential rains caused massive flooding in the state and killed at least 11 people. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Swift told The Associated Press on Tuesday that Louisiana residents graciously welcomed her when she kicked off the U.S. dates of her "1989 World Tour" in the state last year. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "We began The 1989 World Tour in Louisiana, and the wonderful fans there made us feel completely at home. The fact that so many people in Louisiana have been forced out of their own homes this week is heartbreaking," the 26-year-old said in a statement. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The flooding is some of the worst in Louisiana history, damaging at least 40,000 homes. More than 60,000 people have registered for disaster aid from the Federal Emergency Management Agency after widespread flooding hit the state, according to Louisiana Gov. John Bel Edwards' office. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I encourage those who can to help out and send your love and prayers their way during this devastating time," Swift said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Over 30,000 people have been rescued since Friday, with more being brought to safety by the hour.
summary: Louisiana was good to Taylor Swift and now the singer is giving back in the form of a $1 million donation to help victims of the devastating floods that have killed at least 11 people, reports the AP. The 26-year-old says the donation is a big thank you to her “wonderful fans” in Louisiana “who made us feel completely at home” when Swift kicked off her last world tour there. “The fact that so many people in Louisiana have been forced out of their own homes this week is heartbreaking," she says in a statement, urging "those who can to help out and send your love and prayers their way during this devastating time." The contribution isn’t Swift’s first. Last year the pop idol gave $50,000 each to a young fan battling cancer and an ailing nephew of one of her backup dancers, notes US Weekly. Among others: $50,000 to Philadelphia Children’s Hospital in 2014, and $100,000 to flood relief in Iowa in 2008. (For much more on the scope of the devastating flooding, click here.)

text: DEFUNIAK SPRINGS, Fla. (AP) — While his mother was preparing food in the kitchen, a 5-year-old Florida boy called 911 to invite law enforcement officers over for Thanksgiving dinner. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Monica Webster of the Walton County Sheriff's Office tells the News Herald (http://bit.ly/2gs8nkH ) that with all the bad calls they receive every day, this was a happy call. But young Billy Nolin's family had no idea he'd invited guests to dinner. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Mom Landi McCormick says she was cooking when Billy's grandfather noticed him talking to someone on an old cellphone. McCormick reprimanded Billy when he admitted calling 911. He was crying when Deputy Dannon Byrd drove up. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR She says the deputy thanked Billy for his kind invitation, then reminded him he should only use 911 for emergencies. The deputies gave Billy a sheriff's badge. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR ___ NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Information from: The (Panama City, Fla.) News Herald, http://www.newsherald.com  DeFUNIAK SPRINGS — The 911 call on Thursday was short and sweet. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “Will you come over cause we’re eating Thanksgiving,” the young voice with the distinct southern accent inquired. “Thank you. Bye.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The caller hung up the phone immediately, leaving the Walton County 911 dispatcher puzzled, but happy. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “With all the bad calls we take on a daily basis, this one was a welcomed happy call that made all of us smile,” said Walton County Sheriff’s Office Lead Communications Officer Monica Webster. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The caller was 5-year-old Billy Nolin. And he'd extended the invitation to his family's feast without anyone in his house knowing. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR His mom, Landi McCormick, was in the kitchen preparing Thanksgiving dinner with her mom while Billy was outside with his grandfather and his little brother, 4-year-old Camden. Billy was playing with an old cell phone when his grandfather noticed that he was talking to someone. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “I came out and asked him what he was doing,” McCormick recalled. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Billy looked at his mother rather sheepishly and admitted that he had dialed 911. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “I asked him, ‘Why did you do that? You know that you are only supposed to do that if there’s an emergency,’ ” McCormick said. “He started crying, and just a few minutes later Deputy (Dannon) Byrd from the Sheriff’s Office drove up.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The deputy walked up to McCormick and asked if Billy was the young man who had called 911. Rather than scold the little boy, Byrd knelt down and thanked Billy for his kind invitation. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “He told us that Billy had made his day,” McCormick said. “But then he reminded him that we should only use 911 for emergencies.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR As an added treat, Byrd and his partner, Deputy Aaron Ethridge, gave the boy a sheriff’s badge and allowed him to sit in their patrol car and activate the lights and siren. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “They asked him what he wanted to be when he grew up,” McCormick said. “He said, ‘I want to be a cop, so I can be nice to little kids like you are some day.’ ” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Billy said he first became aware of the Walton County Sheriff's Office when deputies visited his school, Maude Saunders Elementary, for Dads and Donuts Day. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I wanted them to have cheesecake with us," Billy said, explaining why he invited the deputies for dinner. "It's my favorite, so I wanted them to have some, too." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR WSCO Public Information Officer Corey Dobridnia posted some photos from the visit on the Sheriff’s Office Facebook page, and the post quickly went viral. Folks from all over the country praised the deputies and Billy for their kindness. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “This is typical of the kind of professionalism our deputies display every day,” Dobridnia said. “It just goes to show that deputies aren’t just about arresting people and putting them in jail. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Billy’s call brightened all of our days, and the deputies’ visit gave Billy a Thanksgiving memory that will stay with him for the rest of his life.”
summary: While his mother was preparing food in the kitchen, a 5-year-old Florida boy called 911 to invite law enforcement officers over for Thanksgiving dinner, the AP reports. Monica Webster of the Walton County Sheriff's Office tells the News Herald that with all the bad calls they receive every day, this was a happy call. But young Billy Nolin's family had no idea he'd invited guests to dinner. Mom Landi McCormick says she was cooking when Billy's grandfather noticed him talking to someone on an old cellphone. McCormick reprimanded Billy when he admitted calling 911. He was crying when Deputy Dannon Byrd drove up. She says the deputy thanked Billy for his kind invitation, then reminded him he should only use 911 for emergencies. The deputies gave Billy a sheriff's badge.

text: Fairfax County police are searching for a woman suspected of impersonating a Target employee and stealing more than $40,000 worth of iPhones. See video. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR WASHINGTON — Fairfax County police are searching for a woman suspected of impersonating a Target employee and stealing more than $40,000 worth of iPhones earlier this month. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Police released surveillance footage Tuesday of the suspect leaving the store. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR On March 15, an unidentified woman impersonated a Target employee at the 6600 Richmond Highway location in Alexandria, Virginia, police said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR She gained access to the stockroom and from there, police said she took the iPhones and put them in a box before leaving the store. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Surveillance footage shows the woman leaving the store and getting into a Volvo station wagon. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The suspect was familiar with store procedures, employee hours and where iPhones were kept in the stockroom. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Anyone with more information about this case can call Fairfax County police at 703-691-2131. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Watch the video below. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Like WTOP on Facebook and follow @WTOP on Twitter to engage in conversation about this article and others. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR © 2017 WTOP. All Rights Reserved.  Detectives in Virginia are looking for a woman who disguised herself as a Target employee and stole more than $40,000 worth of iPhones. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The woman, dressed as an employee of Target, walked into the Richmond Highway store and made her way back to the stockroom. Once inside, she placed the iPhones in a box and left the store, Fairfax County police said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Surveillance cameras were able to capture pictures of the woman. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Detectives said the woman is not affiliated with the store but appeared to know the store's procedures and location of the iPhones in the stockroom.
summary: She wasn't a Target employee, but a woman who sure seemed like one allegedly made off with around $40,000 worth of iPhones from a Virginia store. NBC Washington reports Fairfax County cops are looking for the retail impostor, who they say donned attire resembling a worker's getup, waltzed into the stockroom of the Alexandria location with a box, and loaded the box with dozens of iPhones before taking off. WTOP reports the woman, whose image was caught on tape, seemed to be familiar with how things worked at the store, including employee hours and where the iPhones were stored. Police say the theft occurred March 15, but posted about it on Facebook Monday with a call to "help us nab an iPhone thief." (Target recently had a Boston problem.)

text: ANKARA An explosion from a suspected car bomb ripped through a street in the Turkish capital Ankara on Tuesday near a neighborhood housing government buildings, killing three people and wounding 15, Interior Minister Naim Sahin said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The blast struck the central Kizilay neighborhood less than a kilometer from the prime minister's office, the headquarters of the chief of general staff and several ministries. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Sahin said a parked car had exploded, setting off a chain of blasts as other vehicles blew up on a busy street. The vehicles, like many in Turkey, were powered by liquefied petroleum gas, making them more likely to explode, he said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "It is highly probable that it's a terror attack," he said. "The explosion took place in a parked car, and was followed by explosions of other cars because they had LPG." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR President Abdullah Gul, visiting Germany, condemned what he said was a terrorist attack. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Those who have had no share of humanity carried out a terror attack against civilians in Ankara. We have fatalities. I send them my condolences and with hatred condemn the terror," Gul said, according to state-run Anatolian news agency. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A plume of thick smoke rose above the heart of the city after the blast. Reuters reporters at the scene said a line of parked vehicles had been destroyed and an adjacent row of shops was damaged, across the street from a primary school. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Ambulances and fire engines rushed to the scene and police set up a security cordon while bomb disposal teams' sniffer dogs searched for any possible secondary device. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Sahin said the three people who were killed had been in nearby buildings. Of the 15 people who were wounded, five were in a critical condition. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Kumrular street is a busy place in terms of human and vehicle traffic. It's seen that the explosion mainly targeted people," he said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Kurdish separatists, leftists and Islamist militants have carried out bomb attacks in Turkish cities in the past. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Prime Minister Tayyip Erdogan was in the United States and was due to hold talks with President Barack Obama later in the day. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR (Writing by Daren Butler and Simon Cameron-Moore; Editing by Peter Graff)  A suspected car bomb exploded across a secondary school in the Turkish capital on Tuesday, wounding 15 people, authorities said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR There was no immediate claim of responsibility, but the attack comes at a time when Kurdish rebels fighting for autonomy in southeastern Turkey have escalated their attacks on Turkish targets. The rebels carried out deadly bomb attacks in Turkish cities in the past. Islamic and leftist militants were also behind some bombings in this NATO-member and U.S. ally country. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "There is information that a bomb was planted on the vehicle," that exploded in the downtown Kizilay district, said Deputy Prime Minister Bulent Arinc. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The blast wounded 15 people, said Besir Atalay, another deputy prime minister. At least three of the injured were in serious condition and some of them reportedly lost their limbs. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I felt the blast effect of the explosion some 500 meters (547 yards) away," said Ekrem Erkoc, a 42-year-old eyewitness. "I saw vehicles on fire and an injured man said people lost their limbs." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The injured were initially treated in the school yard before medics rushed to the scene and whisked them away to hospitals, NTV television said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Kurdish rebels were last blamed for a small bomb attack in the Mediterranean resort town of Kemer on Aug. 28 that injured 10 people, including four Swedish nationals. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Kurdish rebels have been fighting for autonomy in Turkey's mainly Kurdish southeast since 1984. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Turkish warplanes have bombed suspected rebel hideouts in northern Iraq last month in response to an escalation of attacks by the guerrillas. Turkey has not ruled out a cross-border offensive against Kurdish rebel bases in northern Iraq.  At least two killed in centre of Ankara by explosion that police suspect was caused by bomb. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The explosion gutted several parked cars before it was put out by fire fighters [Reuters] NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR At least two people have been killed and several injured in an explosion in the centre of the Turkish capital, Ankara, reports say. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Police suspect Tuesday's explosion, which happened in front of the Cankaya local administrator's office close to Ankara's downtown Kizilay square, was caused by a bomb in a vehicle. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The scene of the blast was sealed off as police feared a second explosion, the Anatolia news agency said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The blast sparked a fire which was later put out by firefighters at the scene, NTV television reported. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Television images showed several parked cars ablaze in front of a local state authority's offices, while a plume of thick smoke rose over the area. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR No further details were immediately available.
summary: A suspected car bomb rocked the Turkish capital of Ankara today, and al-Jazeera cites reports claiming that at least two people were killed. No one has yet claimed responsibility, but Kurdish rebels have been escalating their decades-long fight for autonomy and attacking Turkish targets. Rebel groups, as well as Islamic and leftist militants, have all previously used bombs in the country. Reports of casualties are conflicting: The AP reports none, but says 15 were injured, including three seriously. Reuters, meanwhile, acknowledges the reports of two deaths but quotes a local mayor who says no one has died, but that three have been seriously injured. A local news agency has reported that a woman was detained near the scene. “I felt the blast effect of the explosion some 500 meters away,” says one witness. “I saw vehicles on fire and an injured man said people lost their limbs.”

text: Plane 'taxied down main street to Newman pub' NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Updated NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A Pilbara resident has spoken of his surprise at seeing a plane parked outside his local pub after its owner apparently taxied it down the main street so he could get a drink. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Officers were called to the Newman Hotel, also called the Purple Pub, about 2:00pm on Friday. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Witnesses told police the light aircraft, with its propeller running, had taxied from one end of the mining town to the other. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The aircraft did not have wings and was later towed from the pub. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Newman resident Beau Woolcock said he and his five-year-old daughter watched on as the plane was towed away. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "On the way back through [town] ... here's a plane parked outside the Purple Pub," he said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Even more special [was] seeing one of the local coppers poking his head in the door of the plane looking like he was asking for a licence. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Even though no-one was in the plane at the time, I was like, what the hell?" NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Police have charged the 37-year-old plane's owner with an act likely to endanger the life, health or safety of a person. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He also had his plane impounded and was due in the Newman Magistrates Court on November 18. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Newman Sergeant Mark Garner said the incident was being treated very seriously because there were children walking home from school at the time. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He said police had CCTV footage and had spoken to the plane's owner. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "When we arrived we found a Beechcraft two seater prop-driven plane parked in one of the bays," Sergeant Garner said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "There was no-one there. The wings were off the plane. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "We made some inquires with some of the people in the pub and witnesses nearby and ended up speaking to a 37-year-old male." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He said the fact that the plane did not have a steering wheel made the situation very dangerous, and the propeller could also have caused significant damage. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "The danger obviously taxiing a prop plane down Newman Drive, bearing in mind that kids have just come out of school," he said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "It's a busy Friday afternoon. I know it's Newman, but we do get a fair bit of traffic." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Mr Woolcock said the plane had attracted a crowd. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "The plane was empty but they had the fire brigade and the jaws of life there and stuff one of the local guys rocked up with his tow truck and ended up putting it up on there," he said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "There were people sitting around by the Caltex with their phones up taking snapshots... as they would be... you don't get to see that every day." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Witnesses have been asked to contact police. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Topics: police, newman-6753 NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR First posted  A Newman man is set to face a charge of endangering life, health or safety, later this month after allegedly taxiing an airplane with no wings and no steering wheel to the local pub. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The 37-year-old man was charged on Monday night after allegedly taking the propellor driven Beechcraft two-seater aircraft through Newman to the Purple Pub on Friday October 31 at 2.10pm, Sam Dinnison said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR SHARE NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Share on Facebook SHARE NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Share on Twitter TWEET NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Link Police say the plane had its propeller running, its wings removed and was being steered by foot pedals. Photo: Newman Police NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Police allege the man had purchased the aircraft from a man on the other side of town and was taking it home before deciding to stop in at the pub. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR An examination of the plane revealed the fuel line, hanging from the side of the aircraft, was attatched to a jerry can in the cabin enabling the plane to run, and when the man stopped at the pub he left the ignition on. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR SHARE NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Share on Facebook SHARE NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Share on Twitter TWEET NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Link Despite having no wings or a steering wheel, this plane was taxied at a Newman pub NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The man does not hold a pilot's license, and roads were busy with other vehicles and pedestrians at the time. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He will appear in Newman Magistrates Court, facing the charge of endangering life, health or safety, on November 18.
summary: Buying a plane must be thirsty work: Police in Newman, Western Australia, say a man who had just purchased a two-seater Beechcraft decided to drive it home and stop for a beer at a pub on the main street on the way. A resident says he was astounded to see the plane, which had no wings or steering wheel, parked outside the Purple Pub. Even more special was "seeing one of the local coppers poking his head in the door of the plane looking like he was asking for a license," he tells ABC Radio. "Even though no one was in the plane at the time, I was like, what the hell?" After some initial puzzlement over what, if anything, the driver should be charged with, police settled on a charge of "endangering life, health, or safety," reports WAToday. A police spokesman says the incident is being taken very seriously because there were children walking home from school at the time that the man—who doesn't have a pilot's license—was taxiing through the town, using the plane's foot pedals to steer. He passed a breath test at the scene, but police decided to impound the plane.

text: Do you think that the county\'s Unit System form of government has proven to be better for the county than the former district system? NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR I do not believe the Unit System has proven to be better for our county than the former District System. (52%, 12 Votes) NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR I believe the Unit System has proven to be better for our county. (30%, 7 Votes) NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR I do not believe there is any difference at all.
